content: User prefers manual memory creation via gobby-memory tools over automatic memory extraction. Automatic extraction was creating duplicate/junk entries, so it was completely removed from the codebase.

Multi-file coordination is required for feature removal: must update handler registration, workflow configuration files, test files, AND installation templates (both project-local and shared deployment paths) to keep them synchronized.

Complete removal strategy is preferred over disabling/deprecating features. Removing memory_extract entirely eliminated maintenance burden and prevented accidental re-enablement, rather than leaving deprecated code.

The shared installation template (session-lifecycle.yaml) is a critical part of the deployment path that must be kept in sync with code changes. Missing updates there leaves inconsistencies between project-local and shared installations.
After removing a feature that was the sole consumer of an import, clean up unused imports (e.g., json import only used by memory_extract).

When removing features, use grep to identify all references, test classes, individual test functions, and configuration blocks before beginning removal. Test coverage for removed features can be substantial (~800 lines) and scattered across multiple test files.
